name: N,N-Bis{2-[bis(carboxymethyl)amino]ethyl}glycine
Reason: 1,1-Thiobarbituric acid has a melting point of -106.0 degrees Celsius. The basic unit for our comparison will be barbituric acid, which has a melting point of -106.0 degrees Celsius. The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of two additional phenyl rings. Phenyl groups, when connected to a benzene ring, tend to increase the melting point due to the enhancement of the crystalline structure and the increase in molecular weight. In the case of N,N-Bis{2-[bis(carboxymethyl)amino]ethyl}glycine, we have two additional phenyl rings linked in a linear fashion, which would notably augment the melting point. Each additional phenyl group can be estimated to add approximately 100°C to the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions, rigidity, and molecular weight.
